root: ^The smell of wet clothes emanated from the cells.
^The prisoners who were fast or lucky claimed the bunks, while the less fortunate occupied the few spots on the floor by the walls.
^Every single person was exhausted. The journey to the North was long.
^The prisoners were told to wait until morning. At the break of dawn, three old trucks would take them further North, to the Kolyma labor camps.
^Arkady was shivering on his bottom bunk. He was about to turn on his side and try to fall asleep, but he felt someone's eyes on him.
^The stranger had a strong presence. He looked tired like everyone else, yet Arkady could sense that his spirit remained unbroken.
^There are rules, there are circumstances. We cannot ignore them, we must always take them into account.
^People often forget about luck; they don’t believe in it.
^Sometimes, however, Fortuna appears out of nowhere and makes things right.
^Here’s an example. Let's give it a try...
^I know the unwritten prison rules very well. You were here first, and the bed is yours.
^I never ask for anything, but... can I sit here?
^You know, it's been a long and tiring journey.
^You may sit down. But do not forget you're sleeping on the floor tonight.
^Of course. Sit down here, it's hard to stand in such a crowded cell.

c-0: ^See? There’s always a chance of something good happening, even in such a miserable place like this jail.
c-1: ^See? There’s always a chance of something good happening, even in such a miserable place.
^But rules are rules, there are limits. The floor is not the worst option, although I really doubt anyone will be able to catch any sleep in this cold cell.
c-2: ^Ah! Your heart is soft. Don't worry, it won't stay that way for too long.
g-0: ^Thirty years ago, Andreyev was one of the most famous terrorists in Russia. People say he was behind several assassinations of high rank Imperial officials.
^I know you. You were a member of the Socialist Revolutionary Party.
^Former terrorist? I thought you left the country.
^I heard you were a spy. Was it another false accusation?

c-1: ^I did. But they lured me into a trap. Those Soviet agents were quite good, I'll give them that.
^I have no regrets though. No, I wasn't ready to retire yet.
^I wanted to come back and start working. To do what I do best: build resistance against this oppressive state.
^The chances were extremely slim, but I had to roll the dice again and push my luck. Otherwise, I would never have forgiven myself.
^To be honest, I'd rather die here than in France, among all those impotent, boring Russian immigrants.
c-2: ^It sure was. They needed those spy cases for the Purge to happen.
g-0: ^It's quite ironic. The Imperial Okhrana came after me in 1907.
^The officer who interrogated me said I was a threat to the Tsarist government.
^And look at me today! 30 years later, here I am again, doing time in the North for being an enemy of the Soviet state.
^All those sentimental idiots say that The Revolution was a dream that never came true.
^Our 1917, our Revolution, was first and foremost an opportunity. We had our chance... and we lost it. Luck was not on our side.

c-0: ^If you don't mind me asking, was General Kojukh your father?
^Yes. General Valentin Kojukh was my father.
^I followed his public trial. It was a joke.
^You could tell how badly those vindictive party clerks wanted him gone.
^Arkady turned to face the wall, trying to conceal his feelings. The stranger had touched a wound that was still fresh.
^Andreyev felt that, too. For a minute, the old revolutionary became silent, preoccupied by his own thoughts.
^Then, he gave Arkady a long look.

^As you wish. I've heard someone here call you Arkady. That is good enough for me.
g-0: ^Let me give you some advice. Forget about your former self.
^You are a prisoner now; turn your attention to more pressing matters.
^Your body and your mind are about to endure one of the most terrible trials. You will learn what it means to live without freedom.
^Don’t think too much about the past or the future. These thoughts will just make you weak.
^All you have is the present, here and now.
^Distract your mind from counting the minutes of the time you must do in the North.
^Let's play a simple game. It's called $Numbers.
^The game is old; every prisoner is familiar with it, so you better remember the rules.
^This game might even save your life one day, so listen carefully.
^Take this deck, I have a spare one. Keep it close to your heart.
^Now, if you don't mind, I need some rest...
^Andreyev closed his eyes and leaned his head against the cold prison wall. His breath deepened.
^Arkady suddenly felt lonely, and the heavy, uncomfortable dreams of a tired man took over his consciousness.
^A convoy officer woke everyone in the dead of night. Roll call.
^Please accept this as a token of my gratitude for allowing me to spend some time on this bed.
^Keep it. Perhaps, you will meet someone who tried to make the world a better place, but failed. Just like me.
